description: Vietnam's first national university, founded in 1070 by Emperor Ly Thanh Tong to worship Confucius. In 1076, the Imperial Academy (Quoc Tu Giam) was established here to educate Vietnam's bureaucrats, nobles, and elite. It served as the pinnacle of Vietnamese education until 1779, representing over 700 years of scholarly tradition.
highlights: Five distinct courtyards, each with its own function and architectural beauty
82 stone stelae sitting on turtle backs, depicting names and birthplaces of 1,307 graduates from 82 triennial royal exams
Khue Van Pavilion - officially chosen as the symbol of Hanoi in 1997, featuring four round windows representing the sky
Spanning 54,331 square meters of traditional Vietnamese architecture
Night tours with 3D mapping performances about education and ancient scholars
Perfectly preserved example of Vietnamese royal architecture and garden design
